title: How far back does Judaism go? Who was one of the first Jewish people? - Quora

response.answer_text: No one knows. Tradition of course traces it to Abraham; historians do not credit his existence. There are “maximalist” and “minimalist” historians; I’d go with the latter, who use archaeology rather than oral tradition. The Bible is not a very accurate set of documents for making historical assertions the futher back you go. Israel Finkelstein says that Judaism began in the hill country outside Jerusalem; lack of pork bone debris in digs suggest a change among some subset of the Canaanite population occured. see e.g. discussion in Pig Husbandry in Iron Age Israel and Judah Scripture hints at a slow change in theological ideas over time. “Yahweh” was a southern god worshipped in a henotheistic way first, as a god in a group of gods living in a royal court, more akin to Zeus than the Yahweh we know now. Yahweh had a wife/consort; how or why or by whom a true monotheistic idea came about is unknown. Egyptian Aten-worship and Zoroastrian concepts may or may not have influenced it; there is no direct evidence. You could have had “Abiru” (Hebrews) before “Judaism” or a “House of David” tradition without a real David (think “house of Hercules”). By 600 BC with the Babylonian Jews and their ideas and their return you had a core of monotheists, and without monotheism no Judaism. Since they railed against polytheistic rulers and common people still in their midst it appears even then that “Jews” was a self-identifed ethnic group before a unified religious one. You can pick any date before 600 BC and it is little more than a guess. 1000 BC? Become Part of Biblical History has a discussion but keep in mind that “Israelite” may not quite mean “Judaism”if people were still worshipping a polytheistic or henotheistic Yahweh rather than a monothesitic one.
